#100DaysOfCode #CodeNewbie https://t.co/ed6waT8lit

At first frontend devs 'just' needed to know JavaScript, HTML & CSS.

Then they needed to learn Node.

Now they're meant to know AWS and DevOps.

As I've always said, the dev life isn't for you if you don't like learning!

‚ÄúWhich language should I learn first‚Äù?

Depends what you want to do:

* Front end: JavaScript
* Mobile apps: Dart (with Flutter)
* Machine learning: Python
* Backend: JavaScript / Python
To commit to becoming a developer is to commit to continuous learning.

Newbies learning path to web dev glory:

* Build a basic website: HTML & CSS
* Make the website an app: JavaScript
* Make the app with less code: React
* Build a backend / API for your site: NodeJs
* Power your backend with a database: MongoDB / MySQL

After the recent announcement from Google that they will be removing JavaScript from Chrome, and with IE and Safari set to follow, its clear that JavaScript will be obsolete within 12 months.

Time to learn Python.

I don‚Äôt see why frontend devs make six figures, all they need to know is:

JavaScript, HTML, CSS, React, GraphQL, DOM API, NodeJS, command line, Git, webpack, I18N, A11Y, Jest, TypeScript, Docker, Selenium, performance tuning

The path to becoming a professional web dev:

* HTML / CSS tutorial
* Build webpage int HTML / CSS
* JavaScript tutorial
* JavaScript challenges on codewars
* Small web app
* React / Angular / Vue tutorial
* Small web app with chosen library

Did my comp sci degree help me?

It helped my CV

But I‚Äôll tell you this...

Every tech I‚Äôve ever used for work I taught myself outside of university.

A good learning path for #CodeNewbies:

* HTML & CSS -> Build basic webpage
* Basic JavaScript -> Make webpage interactive
* React -> Make webpage a full single page app
* Basic NodeJs -> Build API / Backend to drive your single page app

Learn JavaScript

You get to build server side apps
You get to build mobile apps
You get to build frontend apps
You get to build desktop apps

You get to be a well paid geek.

I have 18k followers, most of whom want to learn to code, yet when I ask,

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your current personal project‚Äù

I get very few responses.

You. Must. Build. An. Actual. Project.
